text: so general anesthesia is is a state
that's produced millions and millions of
times in the world and yet we still
don't have a clue how it works or what
the targets underlying the state of
anesthesia really are a few years ago we
developed a an assay to allow us to
search for new general anesthetics
because the side effects of the current
ones are still very concerning we've
taken this assay screened a half a
million compounds at the at the National
chemical genomics Center in Washington
DC and then using the hits from those
screens we have employed a tadpole a
xenopus tadpole assay to determine
sensitivity and from those we will
determine the best set of compounds to
take to a mammal model to test the
sensitivity of these tadpoles to the
compounds the novel compounds to try to
determine which ones would make a good
anesthetic we put them in these petri
dishes 10 per dish and we set up an
essay a high-throughput essay where we
incubate the tadpoles in the compound
watch them become anesthetized or not if
the drug is no good and then after a
certain period of time we change their
pond water watch them recover and make
sure there's no toxicity associated with
the drug as we're becoming anesthetized
we can check on it several different
ways we can see if they stop swimming we
can also tap on petri dish as they're
going out see if they lose their
elicited startle reflex we have also
used target discovery methods where we
take some of these general anesthetics
we convert them to a photoactivatable
form in the laboratory here at professor
daily in the Department of Chemistry and
we use those photoactivatable compounds
to covalently bind them to their targets
and then search to find out what those
targets are where the sites are in those
Ferguson allow us to use other drug
design methodologies to produce our new
general anesthetics in the hope we will
have new agents in the future that will
allow us to produce the state of general
anesthesia more safely and more
selectively I'm rod eckin hof a
professor of anesthesiology in the
department of anesthesiology and
critical care in the Perelman School of
Medicine at the University of
Pennsylvania
